caption: Joseph Chee Chang: In this video, I will
present the paper title Tabs.do: Task
centric browser tab management. My name is
Joseph Chang and this is a joint work with
Yongsung Kim, Victor Miller, Michael Liu,
Brad Meyers and Aniket Kittur.
So browser interfaces have changed little
since tabbed browsing was popularized
around 20 years ago. However, the way we
use the web have changed dramatically. 20
years ago, most people spend an average of
seven hours online per week. Today, that
number is approaching seven hours per day.
And not only has a significant proportion
of our professional and personal task
migrated to "the cloud". But we also use
the web to support sophisticated
sensemaking tasks involving many web
sources such as product comparison, trip
planning, or home buying.
So the gap between the simple linear
structure of browser tabs and the
complexity of our online activity has led
to serious adverse effects for many users,
commonly referred to as "tab overload". In
this work, we explored the idea of a task
centric approach to tab web browsing, by
designing a browser extension called
Tabs.do
In the development of the system, we have
three design goals, and they are based on
our recent interview in survey study
focused on tab overload issues.
Firstly, users often manage their
attention at the task level instead of on
individual tabs. But it can be costly to
context switch between sets of tabs that
are supporting their different tasks.
And secondly, the linear list of browser
tabs often does not capture the richness
of users tasks.
As a result, users sometimes resort to
copy and pasting URLs and taking notes in
external documents, such as word processor
or spreadsheets, but this can also lead to
high interaction costs.
Unknown: Thirdly, user have tasks that
correspond to varying importance and
urgency. So things like collecting casual
readings from social media to their urgent
tasks and long term projects. However,
browser tabs have the same visual saliency
specifically browser tabs have the same
width, which can make it difficult for
users to stay focused on their important
tasks. So motivated by these core issues
are three design goals were first to allow
users to efficiently group tabs into task
bundles, and context which at the task
level. Secondly, allow users to create
fluid structures that can better reflect
their task mental models. And thirdly,
allow users to prioritize their tabs so
that they can focus on their important
tasks.
So here's the main interface of the
Tabs.do system, which shows up whenever
user opens a new tab after install.
On the left is the main menu where users
can filter their task by projects or
priorities. In the middle is the list of
open tabs, which are automatically grouped
into potential tasks bundle suggestions.
Finally, the main view on the right shows
the nesting structure of saved tasks and
user notes.
Our first design goal was to lower the
cost of context switching at the task
level. One key challenge here is that the
cost of sifting through open tabs to group
all the relevant ones can be very high,
especially for user who has many open
tabs.
So for this, the system generates grouping
predictions to lower the cost of saving
and structuring. It also looks at your
browsing history and use relevant search
queries as the task title when available.
And this prediction is performed in the
browser with a pre trained neural network
to protect users' privacy.
Joseph Chee Chang: If the model made a
mistake, user could also select or
deselect tabs to fix it before saving.
Unknown: After saving a task bundle, user
can close all the saved tabs to reduce tab
clutter. When they need to relaunch a task
context, they can reopen all the relevant
tabs with a single click.
Our a second design goal was to allow
users to create structure that can better
reflect their task mental models. For
this, user can drag and drop their task
bundles to nest them into tasks and
subtasks.
In addition, user could also take notes at
any level in their task hierarchy in the
main interface. They could also do so when
they're browsing a single web page using
this extension pop up interface. This
allows them to use Tabs.do as their
external memory.
Our third design goal was to support tasks
with different types and priorities. For
this the system allow users to assign
types to their tasks to separate them into
different sections: references at the top
and then their unfinished todos and then
their to-read items.
finally completed and deprioritize tasks
are collapsed at the bottom
Joseph Chee Chang: User can also
prioritize their task which sorts them
within each section and assign them a
different color.
Unknown: So that was a high level overview
of the systems. There are more details and
features described in the paper if you're
interested. For evaluation, we conducted a
field deployment study with 10
participants who use the systems to manage
their real world task for one week. We
logged their behavior, and it showed that
they were actively engaged with the system
every day. After the deployment, we
interview each of them for 30 minutes, and
then we coded the transcripts. In general
participants responded favorably about
their experience. More specifically,
participants expressed confidence, saving
and closing their tap with the system.
This is different from prior work that
showed users can often be reluctant to
close their tabs in fear of losing them.
Our participants instead said that the
biggest benefit is being able to close a
bunch of tabs that I had open for days,
and that they know that they could come
back to them easily.
Joseph Chee Chang: So relatedly all
participants also described being able to
context switch at the task level being one
of the main benefits.
Unknown: Participant also said that their
tasks and projects were helpful because
they reflect their task workflow. For
example, one participant had a project
with one task bundle containing Word
documents that they were writing, and then
another task bundle called "analytics" for
the their supporting research.
participants said that they were able to
reduce tab clutter and be more focused on
the task at hand, once said that the
biggest benefit for her was allowing her
to focus on one tab at a time and point it
to how before using Tabs.do, she often
keeps juggling between large number of
open tabs not knowing what to work on.
Finally, we also found seven out of the
10. Participants continue to engage with
Tabs.do every day for more than two months
even after the study has concluded.
To conclude, current browser designs are
becoming insufficient to support modern
online tasks for a growing segment of
users leading to issues with tab overload.
Fundamentally, as our online task becomes
increasingly complex, we also need better
interfaces to help us manage our online
tasks. In this paper, we explore one
direction which is a task centric approach
to tab management. And we found evidence
that it can enable users to efficiently
context switch amongst their tasks, reduce
tab clutter and create structures that
etter reflected their task mental model.
